body: I think we are hitting a race condition where we attempt to update an empty element (once holding a column) with a column again that we are calling `setIn` on the empty element and throwing an error. I made a code change that makes it not error (essentially ignoring the exception if it's an empty component, but I think itâ€™s a poor solution and we need to think of a better solution.

Notes:

- This _is_ a race condition, and it's triggered by Delta coalescing on the server. 
- Removing the coalescing logic from `ReportQueue.enqueue` fixes it
- The issue happens when a `new_element` delta replaces an `add_block` delta. (`add_block` replacing `new_element` doesn't trigger the error.)

issue.title: Fix "'setIn' cannot be called on an ElementNode" error

repository.name: streamlit
repository.description: Streamlit â€” A faster way to build and share data apps.

issue.body:
In the `ReportQueue.enqueue` "Delta composition" logic, we no longer replace `add_block` deltas.

Replacing `add_block` deltas is problematic, because blocks can have other dependent deltas later in the queue. For example:
```python
placeholder = st.empty()
placeholder.columns(1)
placeholder.empty()
```

The call to `placeholder.columns(1)` creates two blocks, a parent container with delta_path `(0, 0)`, and a column child with delta_path `(0, 0, 0)`. If the final `placeholder.empty()` Delta is composed with the parent container Delta, the frontend will throw an error when it tries to add that column child to what is now just an element, and not a block.

(This PR also has type annotations and cleanup for all of `report_queue.py`).

Fixes #3659

body:
@tconkling I'm still encountering this bug. I'm able to reproduce it consistently by way of this simple app:

```py
def main() -> None:
    slot = st.empty()
    slot_container = slot.container()

    # Making slot_container homeless
    slot.empty()

    # Text has nowhere to go
    slot_container.text("Foo")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

```

This might seem like a silly example, but I am struggling with the same issue in a more complex app that I cannot share here.

The script above results in the following message sequence:

```
ForwardMsg:
  delta_path: 0, 0
  delta: add_block
ForwardMsg:
  delta_path: 0, 0
  delta: new_element empty
ForwardMsg:
  delta_path: 0, 0, 0
  delta: new_element text body: "Foo"
```

My guess is that the second message results in the node at `0, 0` becoming an `ElementNode`, and the third message, which references `0, 0, 0` assumes `0, 0` to be a block, and that this leads to issues.

It seems like this should be handled in one of two ways:

1. Either allow this example code to succeed, without displaying "Foo", but also not displaying the error message in question.
2. Fail on the python side, rather than in the browser. That is, calling `slot_container.text("Foo")` could raise an exception.

issue.title: Empty container raises error when written to in a callback

labels.name: status:confirmed
labels.description: Bug has been confirmed by the Streamlit team

repository.name: streamlit
repository.description: Streamlit â€” A faster way to build and share data apps.

body:
Still facing this error but one surprise, it works fine, prints the 'Button_x Pressed' in the terminal pressing both buttons but only gives an error on pressing button_1. The functionality under button_1 works absolutely fine even after the error. Is there any way if i could disable that pop up message or just resolve this?

placeholder = st.empty()
if placeholder.button('button_1'):
             print('Button_1 Pressed')
             placeholder.empty()
             
if placeholder.button('Button2'):
             print('Button_2 Pressed')
             placeholder.empty()

Still running into this issue in 2025 on streamlit 1.41.1 on Python 3.11 - any workarounds?

The trigger for me similarly is creating st.empty() and conditionally filling it later in the script.
